narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I thought the class ran too slowly. We often had lots of extra time at the end of class when more material could ahve easily been covered. I left feeling like I could learn more with the expendature of a little extra effort.

Question 2: Professor Tomlin spent far too much time telling us about the way ESRI programmers think and not nearly enough showing us practical examples of the tools we're given. I estimate that of the total class time for the semester (39 hours = 13 meetings x 3 hours max per) we spent maybe 9 hours actually watching Professor Tomlin show us how a tool was actually used in ArcMap. The rest of the time was reserved for silly anecdotes, attacks against well-meaning programmers none of us will ever meet, and a bizarre habit of ending class early instead of showing us the same tools in several different examples and contexts, as would happen in any other class. As a paying consumer of this school's products, that's not nearly good enough.Unforunately, Professor Tomlin's attitude towards his students was frequently confusing and inconsistent. Grading policies and standards seemed to be all over the map, and several students agreed with me that your "fate" for the semester seemed decided by your first 2-3 assignments. For someone who professes not to care for grading, Professor Tomlin sure does spend a lot of time talking about it, perhaps to justify the absurdity of his system. It's not that the grades themselves were the issue - we're graduate students, it isn't the end all be all - the issue is the closely related and highly stress-inducing problem that we didn't know what was expected of us from week to week, or what the critical lessons and take-aways from each lecture were.Lastly, and most upsettlingly, Professor Tomlin's communications, especially via email, often came across as flippant and unsympathetic to students who were doing their best but remained confounded by his eccentric style. The most bizarre episode was when, during the week of what was considered by many to be the most difficult homework assignment, Professor Tomlin sent out a Word document with a collection of questions and answers that had been emailed to him throughout the semester. But the questions were in no particular order and lacked any labelling that would help put them in context. Most had short sentences for answers, and many seemed to be included more because the questions were "dumb" than because the answers were helpful. It was several pages of glib nonsense, and it was one of the most smug, derisive, insulting things I have ever seen from a faculty member.
My response to question #2, being the teacher was magnificently clear, is completely honest. I can't imagine Dana being more clear, especially with a subject like ESRI's software.

I have never met a professor at Yale or elsewhere as responsive as Dana Tomlin. He replies to emails within 24 hours and always with an answer that solves whatever problem you're facing, no matter how incoherently you as a student describe it. He is a complete master of the material. His self authored ArcGIS handouts are extremely useful.
Lectures were well done. TOmlin is very resposive and helpful via email.

Dana and Eliza were excellent.My only suggestion is that Yale should try to get Dana to spend more time on campus so he can teach the course in two sessions/week. As it is, one three-hour session per week was often hard to take. It sometimes was just too much material. It'd be so much better to have Dana present a smaller amount of material in a classroom with computers and then to have time for students to practice it, and to break the class into two sessions per week. I understand that the classes would have to be smaller to fit into a room with computers. It'd be worth it; students would learn so much more.

The instructor is wonderful - he knows everything and makes himself available to students to an incredible degree.However, the assignments, while the key learning experience in the class, often were frustrating. There were some issues with version 9/version 10 but in several assignments, the wording was unclear and a lot of tinkering was required. Personally, I would have learnt more if I had a clear assignment to follow and then the opportunity to tinker with the program for one or two final flourishes in the assignment. But everyone learns differently!

The work load for this class was VERY heavy, especially for students with no prior knowledge of GIS. The reason I dropped this course was because I did not have enough time to study the worksheets and complete the assignments correctly and adequately.The worksheets compiled for the course were excellent. Very detailed, with plenty of diagrams. I hope to be able to use these same worksheets to learn GIS on my own, with more time, at my own pace.It would have been very helpful for the instructor to mention the immense amount of time the course requires, so that students could have planned adequately.
The Prof. He's great. You'll learn a lot. He's generous and very good at explaining stuff. Take this class, no question.
Clear lectures, explanations and demonstrations
The homework assignments and final project, in particular. They allowed us to engage with the material and really learn it.
Very useful information and skill to apply in almost any context

The best things about this course were Dr. Tomlin and the material that I learned. Dr. Tomlin is a great professor. I really enjoy his teaching style. He is hilarious and never boring. He is also very responsive to student concerns and questions. In addition, I really enjoyed learning about GIS and how it is used.
Dana is a great Professor and very generous with his time.
Dana' clarity in explaining the software.
Very practical
Assignments were really fun.
The instructor was able to bring complex concepts and the architecture of ArcGIS to life in a way that was simple and easy to grasp, yet robust enough to apply to real world problems.
It teaches a very useful tool very well.
homeworks, lectures
Dana Tomlin is a terrific teacher. He's responsive and otherwise explains cumbersome GIS problem in a clear, easy to understand fashion.
The professor's enthusiasm and use of analogies to explain the concepts. Providing instruction for use of the programs themselves was key.
Creative application of ARCGIS
Applicable and helpful for anyone starting out in GIS

Dana's lectures were outstanding. I was a little skeptical of tackling this material in a lecture setting instead of in a lab but he proved that it works well.Although the homework assignments were long and often quite tedious, they were really addictive and quite fun.Dana's animated, kinetic teaching style was also a highlight.I also appreciated Dana's willingness to explain any grade that he had given us. I greatly appreciated his frank comments and willingness to be flexible.
assignments, just grappling with the software.
The instructor's ability to explain things clearly.
Dana's intelligence. Eliza's helpfulness.
The instructor.
The flexibility of the instructor.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The amount of material covered was too small

This school needs GIS education. If anything, it needs more than it has now. Professor Tomlin may be esteemed, but he is ineffective in this context. This class would be most improved by having a professor who was committed to teaching students, not showing them how much smarter he is or ending class 90 minutes early every week.

I think this class should have two TA's. If you go to the computer lab during TA office hours, she's running around like crazy, poor thing, and it's difficult for students to get a good block of time with her.The handouts from the Professor are full of useful information, but they're very difficult to navigate. It can take a while to find which document has the info you're looking for. The Professor should get some $$ to hire a student assistant to turn all those Word docs into hyperlinked text. That would be amazing.
Nothing!
The TA is not helpful at all.
Final assignment was too broad. More specifics (like data options) would have been helpful.
Slow start to the beginning of the course. Some weeks seemed a little more thin on content than others.
Nothing
the instructor made fun of some students and called some legitimate questions "dumb". makes it hard to ask questions in this environment.
I wish Prof. Tomlin was at FES all the time! (&we didn't have to share him with other universities :)

I found it difficult to keep up because I had a laptop that didn't have the power to run ArcGIS well. It was therefore difficult to follow along in class and get that practice in class. This made my learning much slower. If possible, I would suggest providing a few (up to 10?) laptops with GIS for the class time that would enable those students who don't have a laptop or who don't have a powerful enough laptop to be able to follow along as well.
More than one TA or a TA that is enthusiastic and more knowledgeable than the class

There was a lack of clarity about what the final assignment would be. It worked out well in the end, but I would have appreciated a clear explanation well ahead of time.I would also have appreciated 2 minutes per class dedicated to highlighting outstanding work done by my fellow classmates. Dana left the graded homeworks for all to see but it would have been nice to hear him comment in class with a visual aid on some of the better ( or worse) assignments.
Add a second TA. This would help increase the amount of time for one-on-one assistance.
See above.
I understand the constraints, but having the class twice a week instead of once a week would have helped me gain more from lectures. At a certain point, it's just too much.
The course needs more guided lab work as the assignments are difficult for a first time userto figure out on their own.

Perhaps a better way to engage students during class. But this might be very personal- I am not a strong student in technology. I found myself having a lot of difficulty keeping up in class. I know other students had a much easier time than I did.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Extremely quick and helpful responses from both the instructor and the TA.
Adequate, very responsive online even if he could not be around in person.
Excellent. The instructor was extremely accessible, both during office hours and by email.
very available and helpful
Dr. Tomlin was always available for my concerns and questions. I never felt like I needed to receive help from my TA because I was able to work with Dr. Tomlin.
HP+
Great
The instructor anwered my question quickly and clearly. But the TA either didn't the answer to my question, or told me I was doing the right thing which was later proved wrong.
Instructor and TA were very accessible.
Responses were quick and helpful.
Dana was incredibly available. I never sought out the TA for assistance.
great
Eliza was very responsive and almost always spent more time than what was required of her in her office hours to help students.
I did not utilize their time as much as I should have. The TA seemed available; the professor did his best to be available after classes.
Good, From Professor. Excellent, from Eliza (TA)
Instructor extremely accessable by email. TA also responsive by email and avaialble during office hours, but not as helpful as could be if it were someone with more GIS experience

Dana was consistently available via email at all hours of the day and the rapidity with which he responded was astounding. For GIS, being available via email is a far more effective way to be helpful than holding office hours. I contacted Dana frequently via email and he was very helpful each time.I did not use Eliza as much but the one time I went to her office hours she was helpful.
both very high quality
Instructor's help was tremendous -- his responsiveness to email was impressive.
I could not have made it through the class without Eliza's weekly help.
Excellent! Eliza was extremely helpful in office hours and was very patient. Dana, as stated above, is clearly extremely committed and very available to student needs.
The instructor was responsive to comments although more specific feedback is needed on each assignment. More TA scheduled office hour/lab time is needed.
I only approached the TA once. I received very few emails from the TA. She did not seem very engaged. But I only asked for help once.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: GIS is becoming essential to land management.
This course has made me want to integrate GIS into my own ecological research. It is very valuable and interesting.
It will be quite useful for my research!
When I arrived at FES I resolved to graduate with at least one useful, marketable, technical skill. This is it.
I don't know yet, but I know that GIS is a really important thing to know, and now I know it.
This course supports other courses.
Fantastic if anyone wants to conduct any kind of spatial analysis and use maps as a way to communicate trends or data relationships.
Understanding how to use GIS is becoming more and more important.
Great if doing any kind of mapping in your career

This course provided me with an essential set of GIS skills that are great for forestry work and are also very hire-able skills to have.I had little background in GIS and this class jumpstarted my GIS. I will complement this course by taking Raster in the spring.
I want to work in land conservation and GIS is essential.
Good to learn the technical skill of using GIS.
I'm an MF and hope to use GIS in my career. I now have Dana's virtually unlimited offer of help. I'm sure I'll use it!
Basic key skillset.
I thought GIS would be very helpful to my overall training as an environmental manager.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn GIS concepts and programs
I chose to take this course to develop skills that would be useful for representing and analyzing spatial data for my Master's project research.
I took this course because I was interested in learning about GIS and how it is used.
Interest and research-oriented
When I arrived at FES I resolved to graduate with at least one useful, marketable, technical skill. This is it.
Knowledge and familiarity with GIS.
I am interested in GIS.
To learn GIS
I realized that my current job would require how to use GIS.
My own personal enrichment and to determine if this is a skill I can claim when I start the job search.
It is a data integration and communication tool
Wanted basic GIS application knowledge
I plan on using GIS in my career as a forester. It is an extremely valuable skillset.
I need it for my field.
To learn how to use ArcGIS.
I can't not know how to do GIS.
See question 15.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Partially, I wish I new a greater percentage of the programs capabilities
Above and beyond. I've become extremely interested in the material and am looking forward to the raster class in the spring.
Most definitely!
Yes, definitely!
No.
Yes, definitely.
Oh yes!
Yes.
Yes
Yes
Yes.
Yes, and beyond.

yesand no. I understand much better how to use ArcGIS. I don't feel confident that I understand what a workplace setting that wants something done in GIS might want (as examples) and if I am capable of providing that.
Yes
Yes

Yes. Dana did a great job of distinguishing between vector and raster GIS and their respective applicability and I am glad to have taken this class. His lectures far exceeded my expectations for what a GIS lecture would be like.
Yes
Yes.
I wish there was a second semester of vector-based GIS offered. We just got into the analyzing of data and the course was over. A second semester would let us do so much more.
Yes!

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
I feel like I could have done better but I know I learned a lot from the class.
Yes!
Yes, definitely.
Yes
Yes.
Yes
Yes
Yes
See Q17.
Yes; I can continue learning the software now. Got over the threshold
It was more difficult than I expected and quite time consuming
Yes and more.
Yes
Yes.
Yes.
I expected a working knowledge of GIS. If I had completed the homework and exercises, I am sure I would have succeeded in this. However, the time commitment was too great for me this semester.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: NA
I worked on many of the homework assignments with a partner. It was helpful to bat ideas around with a partner and investigate the capabilities of the software with a partner.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Put in the time to make a good homework assignment. The difference between 30 minutes and 60 minutes is a lot in terms of your grade.
Play around with the program, do weird stuff just to see what will happen. Don't just do the assignment and move on.

Spend time playing and experimenting with the software, not just moving stepwise through the homework assignments. The point is to learn how to use and think about the tools so you can use them in your own research. You'll only do that by thinking creatively and experimentally.
Ask for help if you need it.
This is a valuable course if you wanna do anything with GIS-related information!
Don't fall behind! If you do, you're screwed.
Do the tutorials!
Take it!!!
The materials on Class V2 is very helpful. Doing the tutorial will save you a lot of time.

This is a great introduction to themany ways you can use ArcGIS. The workload sneaks up on you so stay on top of it. You will end the semester with a great set of tools to apply to the problems you are passionate about.
If you aspire to a career involving any kind of spatial aspect, I would recommend taking this course. It will give you an idea of just how many ways you can use the tools offered by ArcGIS.
This course is timeconsuming, but expect to come out with transferable skills that you can take to an employer.
Try to make sure you can bring a computer that can run ArcGIS on it. Keep up with the assignments.
Start each assignment early so you have time to consult with the TA well before the due date.
Make sure you have plenty of time. Use instructor, TA and the resource materials provided

1. Email Dana sooner rather than later if you are at an impasse.2. Think twice about even bringing a computer to class. It is often nicer just to take notes and focus on what he does instead of trying it on your own computer.3. Consider working with a partner- it can be very helpful and illuminating provided you set reasonable timelines for getting the work done.
Do the assignments earlier than the night before so you have time to ask Dana questions. Problems ALWAYS come up.
Make sure to have enough time for weekly assignments.
Budget lots and lots of time!
